author: gcolvin
content:
Again - that's a worst case.  And yes, it's an easy transformation -  (Seems operations with dynamic gas costs make it harder, but haven't looked at it yet.)  The problem arises with very short basic blocks that don't do very much computation and the "superblock" optimization doesn't work.  Even when it does work the slowdown can be circa 2X.  Paul Dworzanski says a bit about it here.
https://medium.com/nearprotocol/wasm-for-blockchain-2019-d093bfeb6133

author: .vbuterin
content: hmm, 2x worst case isn't bad; we can always adjust the gas costs to discourage behavior that leads to the highest inefficiencies (just by making jumps more expensive?)

author: .vbuterin
content: Though what's even more important I think is the bigger fact that the bulk of the work in any truly bulky code is going to almost always involve precompiles of some kind (eg. bigint arithmetic, hash calculation)

author: .vbuterin
content: Though surely hashes don't have many conditional jumps and you can just do them with unrolled loops....
